reference.title: Accessibility: Graphs and Charts
reference.shortdesc: This describes techniques and implementation tips to meet IBM Web Accessibility for graphs and charts.

section.title: Techniques for Graphs and Charts
section.p: Sources: Techniques for Web Content Accessibility Guidelines 1.0 - Text equivalents at http://www.w3.org/TR/WCAG10-TECHS/#def-text-equivalent Making Web Pages Accessible to All at http://www.shef.ac.uk/cics/accessibility/graphs.html

Graphs and charts, being visual representations of data, present obvious problems for people with vision disabilities. If the data displayed in the graphic is included in the page text then that is fine, but in most cases charts and graphs contain information in addition to that referred to in the main text. To get around this, the information should be summarized in some form or presented in an alternative form.

Since text content can be presented to the user as synthesized speech or Braille, visually displayed text and text equivalents are required for graphics and audio information. Text equivalents must be written so that they convey all essential content. Non-text equivalents (for example, an auditory description of a visual presentation, a video of a person telling a story using sign language as an equivalent for a written story, and so on) also improve accessibility for people who cannot access visual information or written text, including many individuals with blindness, cognitive disabilities, learning disabilities, and deafness.

section.title: Implementation tips
section.p: Adapted from Source: Techniques for Web Content Accessibility Guidelines 1.0 - Text equivalents at http://www.w3.org/TR/WCAG10-TECHS/#def-text-equivalent

Equivalent information may be provided in a number of ways, including through attributes (for example, a text value for the "alt" attribute in HTML, DITA and SMIL or the "textalt" attribute in IBMIDDoc), as part of element content (for example, the OBJECT in HTML), as part of the document's text, or via a linked document (for example, designated by the "longdesc" attribute in HTML or a description link (D-link)). Depending on the complexity of the equivalent, it may be necessary to combine techniques (for example, use "alt" for an abbreviated equivalent, which is useful to familiar readers; in addition to "longdesc" for a link to more complete information, which is useful to first-time readers).

The method you use would depend on the amount of information to be provided and the most practical way of providing it. For example, if most of the information about a graphic is in the document's text, the text could be enhanced to include the extra information that is conveyed by the graphic. No doubt, it would be a little redundant for sighted users, but it would be more practical than providing it via a D-link or longdesc. It would save time (by avoiding an extra click of the mouse), and it would save overhead by not having an extra file to maintain.
The CORDA Technologies company provides tools such as PopChart that makes accessible charts and graphs with descriptive text and charts.

section.title: Making documentation with explanatory notes more usable for visually impaired users
section.p:
Usability studies have shown that visually impaired users found explanatory notes that accompanied examples more useful when they were placed after the examples. This could translate as best practice for graphs and charts as well -- we should ensure that the user has enough background information about the graph or chart or image, before going into specifics about it. For example, a graph or chart could be described in the text of the document, and then be placed in the document, following which more information about it could be provided either in the text that follows the graph or in screen reader-accessible formats such as alt text,
longdesc descriptions, or D-links.
